awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  On-Demand Color Changing Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will validate the commercial potential of an erasable dye technology intended for apparel. The transformative nature of the approach lies in its ability to reduce environmental impact every time a new design is downloaded. The conventional apparel industry consumes vast amounts of water and emits significant amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2) for every piece of clothing produced. This project aims to drastically reduce these environmental implications while providing consumers with a quick and climate-friendly alternative. By tapping into proprietary light-programmable color-changing dyes, this endeavor seeks to disrupt the fashion industry. By targeting the millennial and Gen Z market segments, which are increasingly conscious of sustainability, the project foresees significant commercial uptake, initially in the $8 billion custom domestic T-shirt market.

The intellectual merit of this project stems from its unique combination of advanced functional materials science, chemistry, and manufacturing to create a sustainable apparel solution. At the heart of the method lies a proprietary dye system which can provide repeatable color changes. Unlike conventional photochromic dyes that degrade quickly under visible light, this dye system is engineered to be durable, enduring repeated cycles of color change. The research objectives focus on refining this dye system to make it commercially viable, especially for the initial use case of custom and re-printable T-shirts. With the successful realization of this technology, the fashion industry will witness a paradigm shift, paving the way for a more sustainable and innovative future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Award Title: SBIR Phase I: On-Demand Color Changing Materials

Federal Award ID: 2304234

Report Submission Period: 02/15/2024 – 01/31/2025

Summary of the Project

This NSF-funded project focused on developing advanced materials using artificial intelligence (AI) to speed up the discovery of new chemical formulations. Initially, the research targeted color-changing (photochromic) dyes, but industry feedback led to a broader application: using AI to optimize chemical formulations fro lab to commercial scale for various industries.

The outcome of this project was an AI-powered software platform that helps companies digitally predict and optimize material formulations, reducing reliance on costly and time-consuming trial-and-error experiments. This technology has the potential to accelerate product development, reduce waste, and improve efficiency across multiple industries, including manufacturing, healthcare, and sustainable materials.

Key Outcomes and Societal Impact

1. Advancing AI in Materials Science

  • Developed an AI-driven tool to assist in chemical formulation and material optimization.
  • Demonstrated AI’s ability to reduce the need for costly lab experiments, speeding up R&D processes.
  • Enabled data-driven decision-making in product development.

2. Reducing Environmental Impact

  • Minimized chemical waste by allowing digital testing before physical production.
  • Improved energy efficiency in material development and manufacturing.
  • Supported the creation of safer, more sustainable materials.

3. Strengthening U.S. Manufacturing and Economic Growth

  • Helps manufacturers reduce costs and increase efficiency through AI-driven formulation.
  • Creates new job opportunities at the intersection of AI, chemistry, and materials science.
  • Supports small and mid-sized businesses in adopting advanced technologies.

4. Improving Public Health and Consumer Safety

  • AI-driven formulation optimization can lead to safer pharmaceuticals, coatings, and consumer products.
  • Helps identify safer and more effective material combinations, reducing exposure to harmful chemicals.
  • Has potential applications in drug formulation, medical devices, and food safety.

5. Transforming Industry with AI

  • Showed how AI can be used in chemical and material development to speed up production and lower costs.
  • Demonstrated real-world success in optimizing materials for various industries.
  • Paves the way for AI-powered smart manufacturing and innovation.

Looking Ahead

This project laid the foundation for using AI in material science, with the next phase focusing on:

  • Expanding AI’s ability to analyze larger datasets and improve predictions.
  • Bringing AI-powered material development tools to more industries.
  • Supporting real-time AI integration into manufacturing for more efficient production.

By combining AI and chemistry, this project is helping to advance innovation, strengthen U.S. industries, and create safer, more sustainable materials for the future.

 


Last Modified: 02/12/2025
Modified by: Raj Bhakta
